ROTC Class Discussions Cause
Controversy Among Top Brass
As a result of the disclosure
to Colonel D. M. Cheston III that
Class time for the upperclassMen has been spent in discusSions of ROTC sponsored social
activities, rather than in the assigned class topics, the question
about the proper use of class
time has been raised.
Casually called the MS IV
Club by a few of its members,
the upperclassmen have spent
a number of the class periods
discussing the problems of the
Successes and failures of the
Military Ball, and the attitudes
Of the ROTC students towards

the presentation of the dance in
the past years. In addition, time
was spent talking about the
Senior Party, a party planned
to make up for one that could
not be held during, this past
Summer Camp.
The Problem
Major W.W. Woodside, who is
the instructor in the MS IV
class, brought the Military Ball
problem to light, since it is his
responsibility to select the chairman and to set up the committees for the Ball. Apparently,
the fact that such a discussion
took place during class time was

Playboy Hits N-1. Story
As'Crude,Suggestive
The News-Letter article of
Oct. 14 on the Playboy Party
held last Friday in the gym was
Called "crude and suggestive" by
Playboy magazine. This opinion
Was expressed by Fred DeKuyper, campus representative of
the pristine periodical, who
added that this is also the
Opinion of his bosses in Chicago.
Concerning the threatened
lawsuit against Roland Blantz,
Chairman of the dance and
against the Cotillion Board and
the Booster Club. DeKuyper
stated that no suit was ever
drawn up and none is contemplated in the future. DeKuyper
explained that Playboy had told
Blantz that he would be sued

for infringement of copyright if
a hired model were given the
title "Miss playboy" or "Miss
Playmate." DeKuyper said he
knew all along that Blantz would
not go through with the announced plans, but that if by
some chance Blantz had not retreated from his position, Playboy would have withdraWn permission to use their decorations
at the dance, and then Blantz
would not only have been sued
for infringement, but also for
unauthorized use of decorations.
DeKuyper told the N-L that
he had attended the dance and
said that it seemed to be a fine
affair, but he was treated with

brought to the attention of the
Colonel, with the opinion added
to it, that such a discussion had
no place in the classroom.
However, Cadet Colonel Mal
Buchner expressed the feeling
that "there is nothing discussed
in class not pertinent to the
welfare of the ROTC Department. Since the Military Ball is
an important activity of the
Corps, even though it is a social

waste of time, but in fact enabled us to plan for a more successful dance."

HONOR
As a result of violations reported just before and during
the spring examination
period, the Honor Commission
conducted four trials. Seven
students were accused in these
trials. They included three
freshmen and four juniors,
and by schools there were
five Arts and Science and
two Engineering students. Of
the seven verdicts, five were
acquittal and two were guilty.
Two freshmen Arts and
Science students were failed
and blacklisted in the course
concerned.
As a result of two trials
held since the opening of
school this year, two sophomore and one junior Arts and
Science students were acquitted of the accusations
placed against hem.

Student polls throughout the
country follow the Hopkins pattern in giving Nixon a wide edge
over his opponent John Kennedy.
A survey released today indicated the following:
University of West Virginia,
Nixon 1,060-Kennedy 783; Montana State University, Nixon
60%-Kennedy 30% - undecided
10%; William and Mary College,
Nixon 53%-Kennedy 33-% undecided 14%; Good Counsel College, a Catholic College for
women, Nixon 152-Kennedy 148,
with • 187 indicating that they
thought Nixon would win.
Southern Schools
Duke University, Nixon 67.5 Kennedy 32.5%, University of
Mississippi, Nixon 1,205, Kennedy 1,046, independent electors
and undecided 438; Roanoke
College, Nixon 307, Kennedy 114;
Marshall College, Nixon 470,
Kennedy 386; University of
South Carolina, Nixon 1,074,
Kennedy 785.
- Drury College, Nixon 61%,
Kennedy 36%, undecided 3%;
Cornell University, Nixon 1,595,
Kennedy 1,503; Rockford College, Nixon 233, Kennedy 101;
Knox College, Nixon 465, Kennedy 260; Morningside College,
Nixon 343, Kennedy 138.
St. Olaf College, Nixon 67.4%,
Kennedy 32.6%; Butler Univer-,ity, Nixon 456, Kennedy 116;
,
University of Pittsburgh, Nixon
46%, Kennedy 43%; undecided
and no opinion 11%; Ohio State
University, Nixon 4,055, Kennedy 2,303; Southwestern University, Nixon 274, Kennedy 152,
Freed-Hardeman College, Nixon
433, Kennedy 57; University of
Texas, Nixon 3,337, Kennedy 1,833.
Kennedy'sSupport
Only two polls showed a student preference for Kennedy.
They were: Delta State College,
Kennedy 143, Nixon 115; and a
joint poll of Notre Dame University and St. Mary's College,
Kennedy 2,600, Nixon 1,900.

In a survey conducted by the
Editors of the News-Letter last
week it was found that 49.6%
of the 300 undergraduates favored the election of Vice President Richard Nixon and 43.1%
favored Kennedy with 7.3% remaining undecided. The faculty
overwhelmingly favored the election of Senator John Kennedy.
The students interviewed came
mainly from two sources. Of the
three hundred interviewed, about
200 were dorm students and the
remainder were chosen at random from the cafeteria at Levering Hall. The faculty were
from six departments: Classics,
English, Electrical Engineering,
Biology, History and Psychology.
The students were asked to answer the questionaire whether
they had made a choice or not,
while the faculty questionaire
was distributed through the mail,
with only a small percentage
answering.
Five Questions
The questionaire asked five
different questions. The first
dealt with the choice of presidential_ candidate. The second set
of questions dealt with the candidates' "debates". The third
and fourth dealt with 'the most
important campaign issue and
the number of people who had
read the parties' platforms.
The fifth question was an inquiry into the effect and the
role of the vice presidential
candidates on the persons choice
of his presidential candidate.
The results were most interesting. It is emphasized that
this is in no way an attempt to
predict the outcome of the national election, but is a fair
guage of how the students at
Hopkins feel and would vote if
given the opportunity.
Vote Distribution
In an attempt to see if any
departmental majors tended one
way or the other, it was found
that the distribution among departments was very similar. For

Goucher-Hopkins Group
Blasts Campus Leaders
The Goucher-Hopkins Coordination Committee, in issuing
a statement to clarify its functions and certain misconceptions
about the committee presently
held by Hopkins students, has
charged campus leaders with
negligence in initiating activities
between the two campuses.
According to Alan Permutt
and Mike Golden, chairman and
assistant chairman of the committee, a misconception of the
committee's functions was greatly enhanced by the insert in the
1960 Hullabaloo on the coordinating committee. That article
accused the Coordinating Committee of not living up to its
functions as a sponsor of integrated activities between the
Goucher and Hopkins campuses.
Al Permutt has stated that it
is the Committee's function to
coordinate activities between the
two campuses, not to sponsor
them; the committee exists to
facilitate participation in co-

activities, not to
ordinated
initiate new ones. That is left
to the various campus organization desirous of co-campus
events.
First Events
•The committee, when first
organized, sponsored two events:
a talk on Pan-American Relations by Dr. Eisenhower and another by Dr. Kraushaar on the
Values of College Students. A
meeting of activity leaders from
both campuses was then held to
suggest•future activities. However, it was left to the campus
leaders to initiate the programs,
not.the coordinating committee.
Their response, according to
Permutt, has been poor.
As a result, the Committee is
now faced with the problem of
stimulating more interest. In a
statement to the News-Letter, Al
Permutt noted, "We have found
that this is necessary to firmly
establish a pr ogr am with

Two cases of vandalism were
brought to the attention of the
DSRC at last Tuesday's meeting.
At approximately 1:15 A.M.
on Saturday morning, some unidentified, and probably intoxicated person or persons uprooted
one of the steel poles which support the chains along the walk,
and threw it through a first
story window in Wood House.
The pole shattered the entire
window pane, bounced off the
bed, rolled on and dented the
floor.
It was pointed out bY DSRC
president Keith Conrad that if
the occupant of the room had
been in his bed at the time, "He
wouldn't be with us now." Towards the end of the evening,
a rock was thrown through a
third story window in the new
dorms.
The depredations were probably the work of two or more
boys, or two different groups of
boys.

Scheduling
The Committee has helped to
schedule these events along with
the Cotillion Board in order to
clear dates. However, the statement continued, "It should be
understood that these calendars
are compiled to a large degree
by the administrations, and we
are therefore unable to make appropriate changes, e.g. Goucher's final exams during Hopkins'
June Week."
Permutt noted that in the recently released Hullabaloo, mention was made of an ice skating
party, the University Prom, and
a Levering Art Show as GoucherHopkins activities sponsored by
the coordinating committee. The
committee however, had little to
do with the sponsorship of those
activities, and had nothing to do
with
the unfortunate time
planning of the Prom or the
initiation of the other activities.
The joint talent show which
was suggested by the committee
and which failed, was sponsored
by the freshman class, not by the
committee, as inferred by the
Hullabaloo.

He said that he and Dean Schaffer have discussed, not without
disagreement, the possibility of
establishing a pre-medical recommendation committee to serve
the function of processing all or
most of medical school recommendations.
Proceeding Cautiously
He was careful to state, however, that he was proceeding
cautiously on this idea as he was
not at all sure just how wide the
authority of this committee
should be. He was vehemently
against giving this committee
the power to prevent a student
from applying to a certain medical school or from obtaining an
outside recommendation. Yet
the urgent need for such a body
is almost universally recognized.
The problem of recommendations was exemplified by numerous comments by students at
the meeting. The difficulties of
frequently changed advisors and
advisors outside of the biology
department were also brought
up.
Confusion
According to the .present system, a student's advisor is considered as the chairman of the
recommendation commit tee.
This, in some cases, has resulted
in considerable confusion on the
part of certain medical schools
when students with different advisors have made application to
the same schools.

Any senior who is applying
to medical school and who desires membership in Alpha
Epsilon Delta contact Arnie
Altman, Box 1203.

The possibility of compulsory,
freshmen attendance at all assemblies was the major topic of
discussion at this week's Student
Council meeting.
SC President Dave Adams
raised the question by stating
that attendance at Hopkins assemblies could be improved if it
were made compulsory that
freshmen attend; that this
would get freshmen in the habit
of attending and they would
tend to come more regularly
their next three years.
Dave Ricci objected to any
such suggestion. He said he
didn't believe a distinction
should be drawn between freshmen and members of other
classes.
Bill Nape complained that the
Council was avoiding the real
issue which was not as much
attendance, per se, as it was the
reasons for poor attendance,
i.e., the quality of Hopkins assemblies; he suggested that if
the assemblies were improved,
the attendance would increase.
Rather than figuring out ways
to increase interest in assembles, it would be better for the
council to "get on the tail" of its
assembly committe.

Missing The Boat
Goucher College is a small girls school whose national
reputation can't compare with that of Hopkins'; yet that
school seems to have an awareness of its role as an educational institution that makes Hopkins' boasts and claims
appear rather hypocritical. Already, Goucher College has
had two major speakers come to her campus: the great
historian, Eric Goldman, and the eternal leader of the
Socialist party, Norman Thomas. Its political activities,
both on and off the Towson campus, have been such as
to cause the Goucher Weekly to editorialize its compliments for the students' enthusiasm, while our so-called
political groups have done comparatively little as Hopkins
organizations. Last year, the whole of Goucher's assembly
program for the year was devoted to searching explorations of urban problems, as she attracted a number of
extremely competent speakers.
*
*
*
This is not meant to be a general glorification of
Goucher College to the detriment of Hopkins; it is meant
to show what a small college can do given a concerted
effort by its students, faculty, and administration.

.REMSEN VAN DE GRAFF

Goucher gets superior speakers because, in the main,
it relies on its faculty to get them; assembly programs,
political activities are channeled and directed by interested
faculty members. Here, students send off letters to major
speakers often only one month ahead of the scheduled
date and expect them to come, while members of the
faculty complain about the demise of Adlai Stevenson and
relegate political activity to an area of the unclean.
Goucher College is successful because it has what
Hopkins doesn't have: a strong sense of awareness that
real education entails far more than the contents between
two covers; that a school's educational burden isn't fulfilled unless it has done more than the bare minimum.
Given the resources, the faculty at Hopkins, it is disgraceful that an election year has come and gone with only
one major political figure appearing on campus—Governor
Robert Meyner of New Jersey last spring.
The futility of the Student Council, an annually
changing body, trying year in, year out, to get speakers
at the last moment, is pitiful to behold. It is obvious that
they cannot do the job. But it is a job that must be done;
the university's assembly program can be an impOrtant
adjunct to its educational program if handled correctly.
We say that the University must take action in this area,
because there are many, many students—not just the
editors of the News-Letter—who are looking toward
Goucher and then back at Homewood and wondering—
Why?

Here at Hopkins, as the ivy
grows methodically over everything on campus that can't run
fast enough to get out of its
way, and undergraduates wander aimlessly around meeting
classes, people we never see or
hear about play with temperatures low enough to kill instantly. Other inconspicuous
people jockey Van de Graaf
generators under our unknowing noses and carry out classified research in ballistics.
Still others operate machines
among the most precise in the
world, and turn out components
second to none in the known
universe.
Rowland Hall houses a low
temperature laboratory which
produces liquid nitrogen which
will, as the man who runs it
casually says, "take the temperature down to about four degrees
absolute." With a little extra
effort, "the technician admits,
"we can take it down to two degrees absolute."
The equipment involved in this
enterprise is one set of only 110
in the world.
Between the wings of Remsen
Hall is a chimney shaped structure which houses something
equally prosaic: a Van de 'Graaf
generator about 50 feet high. The
Remsen generator is not alone
on campus. There is another in
the basement of Rowland.
The Aeronautics building behind Gilman Hall, has always
been a mystery to undergraduates and to most of the rest of
the world, too. So have the quiet,
but doubtlessly important machinations of the Ballistics Lab
at 3566 Greenway Ave., 200 yards
from the new dorms, since it
was closed to the press two Years
or more ago.
Other Hopkins places of quiet
contain the first and most precise set of ruling engines in the
world, and one of the first and
most effective spectography labs
going. The ruling engines scribe
a fantastic number of fine
grooves in glass plate. The plates,
called defraction gratings, are
used by researchers all over the
world to break up light into its
respective colors.
Hopkins, which fathered the
proximity fuse of World War II,
and many other scientific developments of significance, is
still quietly functioning along
these lines. It is doing this in
the midst of 1,434 undergraduates who meet in classes within
a stone's throw of the frontiers
of science, completely oblivious
to the meaning of the whirrings
and clicklings they hear occasionally from behind closed
doors.

THE PARTY WEEKEND: ITS CAUSE
AND CURE
With the season of party weekends almost upon us, my mail of
late has been flooded with queriesfrom young inmates of women's
colleges wishing to know how one conducts one's self when one
has invited a young gentleman for a weekend, so let us today
take up this burning issue.
Well, my dear girls, the first thing to remember is that your
Young gentleman is far from home and frightened. Put him at
his ease. You might, for instance, surprise him by having his
mother sitting in a rocker on the station platform when he gets
off the train.
Next,what kind of corsage should you send your young gentleman? Well, my beloved maidens, orchids are always acceptable.
So, indeed, are phlox and delphinium. In fact, most any flora
Will serve. Do'try, however, to avoid carnivorous plants.
If you find, my esteemed fillies, that your local florist has run
out of stock, do not be dismayed. Make a corsage out of paper.
But pick good, stiff, durable paper—twenty dollar bills, for
example.
Remember at all times, my fond wenches, to show your young
gentleman courtesy and consideration. Open doors for him,
walk on the traffic side of the path, assist him to the punch bowl,
Zip his parka, light his Marlboros.(What, you ask, if he doesn't
smoke Marlboros? Ridiculous, my precious nymphs! Of course,
he smokes Marlboros! Don't you? Don't I? Doesn't everybody
who knows a hawk from a handsaw? What other cigarette
gives you such a lot to like? Such easy-drawing filtration? Such
unfiltered taste? Such soft pack or flip-top box? No other, my
sweet minxes, no other. Marlboro stands alone, and any man
Worthy of you, my estimable damsels, is bound to be a Marlboro
man.)

By JOHN O'DONNELL
The Master of Arts in Teaching program at Johns Hopkins
has proved very successful according to extensive interviews
conducted this week by the
News-Letter.
The Master of Arts in Teaching is a program designed to
provide graduates of liberal arts
colleges additional work in their
field on the graduate level,
teaching experience and certification to teach in secondary
schools.
In attempting to get an evaluation of the program the NewsLetter had interviews with students now in the program and,
graduates of it.

ranged from "satisfactory" to
"excellent." Although there were
some points on which students
did not agree, not one of the
people interviewed said that the
program was bad or that he was
not satisified with it.
Student's Comments

excellent program. It is a good,
quick way of getting a professional degree and still having
more work in the subject matter."
Frederick H. Juergens: "It is
a very good program, the best
MAT program that I have come
in contact with."
On specific points of the program the students, although
agreeing for the most part, did
differ on some aspects.
On the length of the program

twelve month program was very

If you will follow the simple instructions stated above, my
good lasses, you will find that you have turned your young
gentleman into a fast and fervent admirer. There is nothing
quite like a party weekend to promote romance. I am in mind
of a party weekend some years ago at Miss Pomfritt's Seminary
for well-born females in West Linotype, Ohio. Serafina Sigafoos,
a sophomore at this institution, majoring in napkin folding, sent
an Invitation to a young man named Fafnir Valve, a junior at
the Joyce Kilmer School of Forestry, majoring in sap and boles.
Serafina had been ape for Fafnir since high school, but Fafnir
Preferred a girl named Celia Fleshwound, the high school drum
Majorette who once threw a baton so high she impaled a southbound mallard.
Anyhow, Serafina sent an invitation to Fafnir, and he came,
and she showered him with kindness and cuff links, and then
he went away, and Serafina sat anxiously by the mailbox,
Wondering whether she would ever hear from him again. Sure
enough, two weeks later she got a letter: "Dear Serafina, Can
You let me have fifty bucks? Yours, Fafnir."
Whimpering with ecstasy, she ran to the bank and withdrew
the money and mailed it to him. From then on, she got the
Same request every week, and as a result, she became very well
acquainted with Ralph T. Involute, teller of the West Linotype
Bank and Trust Co., and their friendship ripened into love, and
today they are happily married and live in Stamen, Oregon,

cation and the problem of certification of teachers. Most students felt that some education
courses are necessary, but the
amount necessary was a point on
which each had a different
Opinion.
Mr. Juergens felt that the education courses are "for the most
part a complete waste of time.
Certification is too strict as far

Miss Marian Brischle: "There

of subject matter. You do need

William
Vandervliet: "The

courses is not too good. But they
make you aware of the field you
are getting into."
Miss Carlson stated that the
education courses "make you
aware of the problems in the
field of education, the problems
of mass education."
Good Preparation
The students were unanimous
in stating that the MAT program is a better preparation for
secondary school teaching than
majoring in education as an
undergraduate.
None of the students interviewed saw any major drawbacks to the program.
The financial arrangement of
the MAT program proved to be
one of its most popular features.
In addition to getting grants
from the Fund for the Advancement of Education, the students
are paid the salary of an uncertified teacher for the semester
they spend teaching.
MAT graduates agreed with
the students on the merits of the
program. All stated that they
were satisfied with it and none
could see any major drawbacks.
One criticism that graduates
of the first two years of the
program voiced was on the matter of certification by the state
to teach.
Mr. Armond Opitz and Mrs.
Suzanne Diffenbaugh stated that
MAT graduates had trouble getting their certification immediately.
A check with the Maryland
State Department of Education
revealed that at one time there
was a difficulty over certification
of MAT graduates.
Certification Problems
Miss Eleanor Rice, Supervisor
of Certification, said that the internship teaching in the MAT
program had not provided for
any supervision of the students
while they were teaching and
that a minimum of 25 hours of
supervision is required for certification.
However, Miss Rice added that

the difficulty has b2en cleared
up and that the MAT students
now get the required supervision.
Recently the MAT office conducted a survey concerning the
progress of MAT graduates.
Results of the survey reveal
that, on the whole, administrators are very pleased with the
work of these people.

miniature "neW arts" products that are changing the science
of communications. It's a job which offers you a challenging career—a chance to plan new method.; of mass producing ever-improving kinds of transistor"; ferrite devices,

this field. At present our Allentown and Latu-eldale, Pa.,

and a big new plant- is under construction in Kansas City.
The needs of the Bell Telephone System for these products

In their busiest week of the
Year, the Hopkins soccer team
continued to roll along towards
one of its best seasons ever.
At the end of six games the
rnen from Homewood are sporting a 5-1 record. The Jays record
in Middle
Atlantic play stands
at 3-1, and in
the Mason-Dixon
they are 2-0.
On Wednesday, Oct. 26, the
home forces travelled to Gettysburg to face the winless Bullets.
0-burg opened the scoring, but
the Bluejays bounced right back
as Sal Cuomo fed to Don Even80n, who headed the ball past the
Bullet goalie. Still in the second
quarter, Cuomo added to his goal
total as one of the Bullet fullbacks mis-kicked the ball, and
scored for the Blue. As Cuomo
Was the last Jay player to touch
the ball he
was credited with the
goal. Just before half-time the
locals scored again and left the
field at intermission enjoying a
3-1 lead.

By IRV NATHAN

say aboat the team's performance during the last week, "As
the season continues the misfortune at Gettysburg grows bigger. We ran into a team that
was really up for the game and
caught us on a bad day, as we
played way below our potential.
We were leading 3-1 at half time,
and blew the game 5-3. Our defense completely went to pieces
and panicked, as they forgot our
three back-safety back style of
play. Time and again they overshifted the defenses in front of
the goal, leaving Gettysburg
players all alone waiting to score
when they got the ball.

As a result of violations reported just before and during
the spring examination
period, the Honor Commission
conducted four trials. Seven

In a survey conducted by the
Editors of the News-Letter last
week it was found that 49.6%
of the 300 undergraduates favored the election of Vice President Richard Nixon and 43.1%
favored Kennedy with 7.3% remaining undecided. The faculty
overwhelmingly favored the election of Senator John Kennedy.
The students interviewed came
mainly from two sources. Of the
three hundred interviewed, about
200 were dorm students and the
remainder were chosen at random from the cafeteria at Levering Hall. The faculty were
from six departments: Classics,
English, Electrical Engineering,
Biology, History and Psychology.
The students were asked to answer the questionaire whether
they had made a choice or not,
while the faculty questionaire
was distributed through the mail,
with only a small percentage
answering.
Five Questions
The questionaire asked five
different questions. The first
dealt with the choice of presidential_ candidate. The second set
of questions dealt with the candidates' "debates". The third
and fourth dealt with 'the most
important campaign issue and
the number of people who had
read the parties' platforms.
The fifth question was an inquiry into the effect and the
role of the vice presidential
candidates on the persons choice
of his presidential candidate.
The results were most interesting. It is emphasized that
this is in no way an attempt to
predict the outcome of the national election, but is a fair
guage of how the students at
Hopkins feel and would vote if
given the opportunity.

Proceeding Cautiously
He was careful to state, however, that he was proceeding

The problem of recommendations was exemplified by numerous comments by students at

Confusion
According to the .present system, a student's advisor is considered as the chairman of the
recommendation commit tee.
This, in some cases, has resulted
in considerable confusion on the
part of certain medical schools
when students with different advisors have made application to
the same schools.

The possibility of compulsory,
freshmen attendance at all assemblies was the major topic of
discussion at this week's Student
Council meeting.
SC President Dave Adams
raised the question by stating
that attendance at Hopkins assemblies could be improved if it
were made compulsory that
freshmen attend; that this
would get freshmen in the habit
of attending and they would
tend to come more regularly
their next three years.
Dave Ricci objected to any
such suggestion. He said he
didn't believe a distinction
should be drawn between freshmen and members of other
classes.
Bill Nape complained that the
Council was avoiding the real
issue which was not as much
attendance, per se, as it was the
reasons for poor attendance,
i.e., the quality of Hopkins assemblies; he suggested that if
the assemblies were improved,
the attendance would increase.
Rather than figuring out ways
to increase interest in assembles, it would be better for the
council to "get on the tail" of its
assembly committe.

Missing The Boat
Goucher College is a small girls school whose national
reputation can't compare with that of Hopkins'; yet that
school seems to have an awareness of its role as an educational institution that makes Hopkins' boasts and claims
appear rather hypocritical. Already, Goucher College has
had two major speakers come to her campus: the great
historian, Eric Goldman, and the eternal leader of the
Socialist party, Norman Thomas. Its political activities,
both on and off the Towson campus, have been such as
to cause the Goucher Weekly to editorialize its compliments for the students' enthusiasm, while our so-called
political groups have done comparatively little as Hopkins
organizations. Last year, the whole of Goucher's assembly
program for the year was devoted to searching explorations of urban problems, as she attracted a number of
extremely competent speakers.
*
*
*
This is not meant to be a general glorification of
Goucher College to the detriment of Hopkins; it is meant
to show what a small college can do given a concerted
effort by its students, faculty, and administration.

.REMSEN VAN DE GRAFF

Goucher gets superior speakers because, in the main,
it relies on its faculty to get them; assembly programs,
political activities are channeled and directed by interested
faculty members. Here, students send off letters to major
speakers often only one month ahead of the scheduled
date and expect them to come, while members of the
faculty complain about the demise of Adlai Stevenson and
relegate political activity to an area of the unclean.
Goucher College is successful because it has what
Hopkins doesn't have: a strong sense of awareness that
real education entails far more than the contents between
two covers; that a school's educational burden isn't fulfilled unless it has done more than the bare minimum.
Given the resources, the faculty at Hopkins, it is disgraceful that an election year has come and gone with only
one major political figure appearing on campus—Governor
Robert Meyner of New Jersey last spring.
The futility of the Student Council, an annually
changing body, trying year in, year out, to get speakers
at the last moment, is pitiful to behold. It is obvious that
they cannot do the job. But it is a job that must be done;
the university's assembly program can be an impOrtant
adjunct to its educational program if handled correctly.
We say that the University must take action in this area,
because there are many, many students—not just the
editors of the News-Letter—who are looking toward
Goucher and then back at Homewood and wondering—
Why?

Here at Hopkins, as the ivy
grows methodically over everything on campus that can't run
fast enough to get out of its
way, and undergraduates wander aimlessly around meeting
classes, people we never see or
hear about play with temperatures low enough to kill instantly. Other inconspicuous
people jockey Van de Graaf
generators under our unknowing noses and carry out classified research in ballistics.
Still others operate machines
among the most precise in the
world, and turn out components
second to none in the known
universe.
Rowland Hall houses a low
temperature laboratory which
produces liquid nitrogen which
will, as the man who runs it
casually says, "take the temperature down to about four degrees
absolute." With a little extra
effort, "the technician admits,
"we can take it down to two degrees absolute."
The equipment involved in this
enterprise is one set of only 110
in the world.
Between the wings of Remsen
Hall is a chimney shaped structure which houses something
equally prosaic: a Van de 'Graaf
generator about 50 feet high. The
Remsen generator is not alone
on campus. There is another in
the basement of Rowland.
The Aeronautics building behind Gilman Hall, has always
been a mystery to undergraduates and to most of the rest of
the world, too. So have the quiet,
but doubtlessly important machinations of the Ballistics Lab
at 3566 Greenway Ave., 200 yards
from the new dorms, since it
was closed to the press two Years
or more ago.
Other Hopkins places of quiet
contain the first and most precise set of ruling engines in the
world, and one of the first and
most effective spectography labs
going. The ruling engines scribe
a fantastic number of fine
grooves in glass plate. The plates,
called defraction gratings, are
used by researchers all over the
world to break up light into its
respective colors.
Hopkins, which fathered the
proximity fuse of World War II,
and many other scientific developments of significance, is
still quietly functioning along
these lines. It is doing this in
the midst of 1,434 undergraduates who meet in classes within
a stone's throw of the frontiers
of science, completely oblivious
to the meaning of the whirrings
and clicklings they hear occasionally from behind closed
doors.

THE PARTY WEEKEND: ITS CAUSE
AND CURE
With the season of party weekends almost upon us, my mail of
late has been flooded with queriesfrom young inmates of women's
colleges wishing to know how one conducts one's self when one
has invited a young gentleman for a weekend, so let us today
take up this burning issue.
Well, my dear girls, the first thing to remember is that your
Young gentleman is far from home and frightened. Put him at
his ease. You might, for instance, surprise him by having his
mother sitting in a rocker on the station platform when he gets
off the train.
Next,what kind of corsage should you send your young gentleman? Well, my beloved maidens, orchids are always acceptable.
So, indeed, are phlox and delphinium. In fact, most any flora
Will serve. Do'try, however, to avoid carnivorous plants.
If you find, my esteemed fillies, that your local florist has run
out of stock, do not be dismayed. Make a corsage out of paper.
But pick good, stiff, durable paper—twenty dollar bills, for
example.
Remember at all times, my fond wenches, to show your young
gentleman courtesy and consideration. Open doors for him,
walk on the traffic side of the path, assist him to the punch bowl,
Zip his parka, light his Marlboros.(What, you ask, if he doesn't
smoke Marlboros? Ridiculous, my precious nymphs! Of course,
he smokes Marlboros! Don't you? Don't I? Doesn't everybody
who knows a hawk from a handsaw? What other cigarette
gives you such a lot to like? Such easy-drawing filtration? Such
unfiltered taste? Such soft pack or flip-top box? No other, my
sweet minxes, no other. Marlboro stands alone, and any man
Worthy of you, my estimable damsels, is bound to be a Marlboro
man.)

G-H Sophomores
To Raffle 'Doll
At Talent Show
In an exclusive interview with
the News-Letter, it was revealed
today that the talent show
.
sponsored by the combined
Sophomore classes of Goucher
and Hopkins will take place as
scheduled on November 11 at
eight o'clock in Goucher's barn.
The entertainment will consist of a series of skits with the
theme, "Fraternities Through
the Ages," and will be followed
by an informal party. To add
interest, the holder of the lucky
ticket will get a date for the
party with a Danish exchange
student who is described by a
reliable source as "a doll."
